user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS O_NONBLOCK
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the two calls that invoke strerror(...) are related to the <string.h> family in the provided function. These calls should be investigated to ensure the use of string-handling facilities does not lead to out-of-bounds accesses. All other fragments in the function are not uses of the <string.h> API and therefore do not fall under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17: - Calls to fcntl(...) operate on integer file descriptors/flags, not string buffers. - Bitwise operations (os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS) and comparisons (os_flags == -1) do not involve string handling. - The assignment impl->selectable = true and the retrieval impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...) do not involve string functions or pointer parameters to <string.h> functions. - The macro OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS is an integer constant (O_NONBLOCK) and unrelated to string buffer manipulation. Consequently, no other code fragments require investigation for Rule 21.17 compliance based on the supplied code.
